description:
From Middle English penetracioun, from Old French penetracïon, and its source, Latin penetrātiō, from the participle stem of penetrō (“pierce”, verb).
Morphologically penetrate +‎ -ion

entries.meaning: The act of penetrating something. [from 15th c.]
examples: Any penetration, however slight, is sufficient to complete the offense.

entries.meaning: Specifically, the insertion of the penis (or similar object) during sexual intercourse. [from 17th c.]
The act of penetrating a given situation with the mind or faculties; perception, discernment. [from 17th c.]
examples: I have no respect for the penetration of any man who can read the report of that conversation, and still call the principal in it insane.

entries.meaning: (blackjack) A number or fraction that represents how many cards/decks will be dealt before shuffling, in contrast to the total number of cards/decks in play.
(marketing) The proportion of the target audience who buy the advertised product or service.
